issue.title: s/conflicting packages/other packages/
issue.body: The term "conflicting packages" is inaccurate, because with the alternatives system, multiple packages can provide the same man page without conflicting with each other.

comment.body:
You’re right in that the packages don’t conflict with each other at the Debian package level, but from a logical perspective (detached from any technical details), there still is a conflict: there are multiple manual pages for the same name.

I don’t mind changing the terminology to be more descriptive, but at the same time, I’m not convinced that switching from “conflicting” to “other” is an improvement: “other” isn’t describing anything at all. As a reader, I can ask “sure, it’s another package, but what’s the relationship?”

I’m inclined to leave it as “conflicting”

issue.title: Missing alternative: pager → more
issue.body:
`util-linux` installs `more.1` as an alternative for `pager.1`, but is not listed on <https://manpages.debian.org/unstable/less/pager.1.en.html>.
I guess it's because the package is essential?

comment.body:
You can learn more about how the alternatives integration works in https://github.com/Debian/debiman/issues/12

When I download https://piuparts.debian.org/for-manpages.d.o/sid.json.gz, I don’t see an entry for `util-linux`. Maybe you can take a look and figure out what’s wrong?

issue.title: [Umbrella] Support gaps

labels.name: accepted
labels.description: Has been approved and is ok to start working on

labels.name: merge-i3-gaps
labels.description: Issues needing to be resolved to deprecate i3-gaps

issue.body:
## Known issues / possible improvements - [x] Ensure gaps work with titlebars without a compositor: https://github.com/i3/i3/issues/1966 - [ ] Window size isn’t evenly distributed, in particular with large gaps - [ ] Potentially make the gaps configuration no longer order-sensitive --- Original issue text: ## Desired Behavior After a recent discussion between @stapelberg and myself, we would like to reconsider bringing gaps into i3 itself, effectively deprecating i3-gaps. The main rationale here is that there clearly are thousands of users who want gaps. In order to do so, we need to implement not only gaps, but also all of the current i3-gaps features as listed below. This issue serves as an umbrella issue, if necessary we can create separate issues for the individual features. Before work on this can be started, we need to state our expectations: 1. This is **not** about simply porting the gaps patch into i3. The current gaps patch is kept simple enough to make upstream maintenance possible; this means, however, that in many ways it is more of a hack and doesn't live up to our quality expectations. We should therefore consider – and discuss – how gaps can be brought into i3 in a clean way, particularly including support for titlebars. 2. At this point in time, there is no final decision on whether we would merge this. It very much depends on the discussion and the solution we can find. # Gaps This list tracks the core gaps features that need to be supported - [x] Current i3-gaps configuration and command surface: - Configuration: `gaps [inner|outer|horizontal|vertical|top|left|bottom|right] ` - Configuration: `workspace gaps [inner|outer|horizontal|vertical|top|left|bottom|right] ` - Command: `gaps inner|outer|horizontal|vertical|top|right|bottom|left current|all set|plus|minus|toggle ` - [x] Make gaps information properly available on the IPC (required for in-place restart) - [x] Provide tests for gaps We should overall strive to be compatible with i3-gaps to minimize friction, but where sensible we may deviate. For example, workspace-level gaps are currently solved a bit awkward in i3-gaps. # Gaps-related features The following list tracks other features that need to be supported in i3 as well¹. - [x] `smart_gaps on | inverse_outer` - [x] `smart_borders no_gaps`² - [x] `hide_edge_borders smart_no_gaps` ¹ Note that we may choose to rename features if necessary. ² `smart_borders on` is an alias for `hide_edge_borders smart` and will thus be ignored here. Linking related issues for visibility: #1474, #3611, #2890 Please keep the discussion on this issue solely about how to move gaps to i3. Other questions or feature requests should be posted as new issues. As this will likely be a long and technical discussion I will hide any off topic comments. Thank you! ## Environment Output of `i3 --moreversion 2>&-`: 
i3 version: 4.16.1

comment.body:
> I have switched to next. I am only using `inner gaps 10` in my configuration and I had to switch to `inner gaps 5` to get the same gaps. Otherwise, everything seems to run smoothly.

You’re probably using 2x scaling on a hi-dpi display then? We added hi-dpi support to gaps, but the consequence is the change you needed :) https://github.com/i3/i3/commit/6b658f88be50d5251f85eaf6f838d6c67ebaac95

comment.body:
No, sur5r has taken over the Debian packaging work since i3 v4.17 (thank you!)

I have considered doing a release with this feature earlier than the usual cadence because of its significance. 

The earliest I can imagine is early/mid December, or possibly January depending on how many user reports we get in terms of breakage or successful test reports.

Debian’s soft freeze starts at 2023-02-12, so with a release in January (preferably early), that would leave sur5r a few weeks to upload it to Debian to make it into bookworm.

issue.title: Draw decorations on own frame for V/H

labels.name: tentatively_accepted
labels.description: This feature has been previously accepted, but needs to be re-evaluated now.

issue.body:
@stapelberg I wonder if there is a good reason why we draw window decorations on the parent container? I understand that it's a design decision that is deeply integrated into the i3 code, but I'd still like to figure out whether it's something we could consider changing given someone does the work.

For stacked and tabbed containers it makes a lot of sense, but I'm not sure this applies to vertically or horizontally split containers as well.
- Is there an actual, technical reason for this? Can we anticipate changes other than the rendering that would become necessary?
- Is it something that could be considered to be changed?

i3 4.10.4

issue.title: Starting containers fails
issue.body:
I ran through the instructions in the README (which is, BTW, different from the ones [on the website](https://gokrazy.org/packages/docker-containers/)) and when it came to running a container, I got the following error messages:

```go
/tmp/breakglass4160648770 # podman run --rm -ti docker.io/library/debian:sid
Trying to pull docker.io/library/debian:sid...
Getting image source signatures
Copying blob 63a396bb133c done  
Copying config dba65145f2 done  
Writing manifest to image destination
Storing signatures
WARN[0051] Failed to load cached network config: network podman not found in CNI cache, falling back to loading network podman from disk 
WARN[0051] 1 error occurred:                        
                            	* plugin type="cni-nftables-firewall" failed (delete): cni plugin cni-nftables-firewall failed: cni-nftables-firewall.Del() error: failed validating input: the data passed to firewall plugin did not contain network interfaces
   
Error: plugin type="bridge" failed (add): cni plugin bridge failed: failed to create bridge "cni-podman0": could not add "cni-podman0": operation not supported
```

I don't know enough about all of this to know where to even start debugging this further. 

I have `/perm/container-storage` bind-mounted to `/var`. Version info from the web interface is

```
version 2022-11-04T21:04:24+01:00
host	gokrazy
kernel	Linux 5.7.6 (aarch64)
model	Raspberry Pi 3 Model B Rev 1.2
```

Any hints on what to try?

comment.body:
> I feel with the way it works now `builddir` is a misnomer. `builddir`, to me, suggests that it's a temporary directory for build artifacts, whereas it seems to rather be a source of truth.
> 
> Obviously, it works the way it works. I think there are better alternatives, but this doesn't seem the right place and time to discuss it.

Yes, it’s definitely a source of truth (for the build of each package, hence the current name). I’m open for better names if you have one :) 

> I have instance-specific code. It needs to live in a module. AIUI (now) I should perhaps put that into `builddir`, though.

No, I don’t think it should go into a builddir. In the builddir, only go.mod and go.sum are expected to be present.

What are you trying to achieve by moving your module/package’s code into the builddir?

issue.title: Starting containers fails
issue.body:
I ran through the instructions in the README (which is, BTW, different from the ones [on the website](https://gokrazy.org/packages/docker-containers/)) and when it came to running a container, I got the following error messages:

```go
/tmp/breakglass4160648770 # podman run --rm -ti docker.io/library/debian:sid
Trying to pull docker.io/library/debian:sid...
Getting image source signatures
Copying blob 63a396bb133c done  
Copying config dba65145f2 done  
Writing manifest to image destination
Storing signatures
WARN[0051] Failed to load cached network config: network podman not found in CNI cache, falling back to loading network podman from disk 
WARN[0051] 1 error occurred:                        
                            	* plugin type="cni-nftables-firewall" failed (delete): cni plugin cni-nftables-firewall failed: cni-nftables-firewall.Del() error: failed validating input: the data passed to firewall plugin did not contain network interfaces
   
Error: plugin type="bridge" failed (add): cni plugin bridge failed: failed to create bridge "cni-podman0": could not add "cni-podman0": operation not supported
```

I don't know enough about all of this to know where to even start debugging this further. 

I have `/perm/container-storage` bind-mounted to `/var`. Version info from the web interface is

```
version 2022-11-04T21:04:24+01:00
host	gokrazy
kernel	Linux 5.7.6 (aarch64)
model	Raspberry Pi 3 Model B Rev 1.2
```

Any hints on what to try?

comment.body:
> But I used a new `gokr-packer`, I would expect that to pick up new versions of the kernel and other packages…

The packer never updates for you (I think the `go` tool doesn’t, either). In my update script, I do:

```bash
for instance in dr bakery scan2drive bakeryapu2c4 consrv; do
    echo "pulling instance $instance"
    cd ~/gokrazy/$instance/builddir/github.com/gokrazy/gokrazy
    go get github.com/gokrazy/gokrazy@latest

    if [ "$instance" = "bakeryapu2c4" ]
    then
	cd ~/gokrazy/$instance/builddir/github.com/rtr7/kernel
	go get github.com/rtr7/kernel@latest
    else
	cd ~/gokrazy/$instance/builddir/github.com/gokrazy/kernel
	go get github.com/gokrazy/kernel@latest

	cd ~/gokrazy/$instance/builddir/github.com/gokrazy/firmware
	go get github.com/gokrazy/firmware@latest

	cd ~/gokrazy/$instance/builddir/github.com/gokrazy/rpi-eeprom
	go get github.com/gokrazy/rpi-eeprom@latest
    fi
done

```

(Plus some update-specific instance logic where appropriate, but for some programs it’s a feature that they won’t get updated until I say so.)

> or use the one from the `go.mod` in the current module

It does that, but the “current module” is in the builddir. The top-level go.mod is only used as a template for creating new builddirs where necessary (which can be useful if you want e.g. `replace` directives to apply to all new modules).

It might be clearer to delete any top-level go.mod you have in your instance directories.

issue.title: Starting containers fails
issue.body:
I ran through the instructions in the README (which is, BTW, different from the ones [on the website](https://gokrazy.org/packages/docker-containers/)) and when it came to running a container, I got the following error messages:

```go
/tmp/breakglass4160648770 # podman run --rm -ti docker.io/library/debian:sid
Trying to pull docker.io/library/debian:sid...
Getting image source signatures
Copying blob 63a396bb133c done  
Copying config dba65145f2 done  
Writing manifest to image destination
Storing signatures
WARN[0051] Failed to load cached network config: network podman not found in CNI cache, falling back to loading network podman from disk 
WARN[0051] 1 error occurred:                        
                            	* plugin type="cni-nftables-firewall" failed (delete): cni plugin cni-nftables-firewall failed: cni-nftables-firewall.Del() error: failed validating input: the data passed to firewall plugin did not contain network interfaces
   
Error: plugin type="bridge" failed (add): cni plugin bridge failed: failed to create bridge "cni-podman0": could not add "cni-podman0": operation not supported
```

I don't know enough about all of this to know where to even start debugging this further. 

I have `/perm/container-storage` bind-mounted to `/var`. Version info from the web interface is

```
version 2022-11-04T21:04:24+01:00
host	gokrazy
kernel	Linux 5.7.6 (aarch64)
model	Raspberry Pi 3 Model B Rev 1.2
```

Any hints on what to try?

comment.body:
Try installing these packages:

* [github.com/greenpau/cni-plugins/cmd/cni-nftables-portmap](http://github.com/greenpau/cni-plugins/cmd/cni-nftables-portmap) 
* [github.com/greenpau/cni-plugins/cmd/cni-nftables-firewall](http://github.com/greenpau/cni-plugins/cmd/cni-nftables-firewall)

I think if you use `--net=host`, it should work without the packages, too

We should update the documentation afterwards, so please let me know how it goes :)

issue.title: draw leaf window decorations on ->frame instead of ->parent->frame
issue.body:
This fixes the graphical artifacts when gaps are enabled with title bars.

Not yet done (will update the PR):

* [ ] documentation update (hacking-howto, userguide)
* [ ] in `layout stacked` and `layout tabbed`, the terminal contents are one line short for some reason (wrong calculation somewhere?)

related to https://github.com/i3/i3/issues/3724

comment.body:
> This closes #1966 I believe

Yep, the “fixes #1966” is already in the commit message (but not on the pull request level).

> I also wonder how you're feeling about [#1966 (comment)](https://github.com/i3/i3/issues/1966#issuecomment-158684486)?

I haven’t thought it through in detail.

On one hand, one could say that the deco_rect semantics are unchanged, only the rendering has changed — the deco_rect still specifies *where* the decoration is drawn, but now the drawing happens on a different X11 window.

I think the way we interpreted “retain semantics” in the past (at least in that issue) is to translate coordinates in such a way that the x/y position still matches the absolute position on screen where decorations appear today.

I wonder how widely used the deco_rect is by IPC interface users at all. The only usages I can find on GitHub Code Search that might be affected are https://github.com/cornerman/i3-easyfocus and https://github.com/kraftwerk28/dotfiles/blob/bd081348da1dfdc126db95563b534a7669e990bd/bin/grimvshot#L35

I’ll try and see if i3-easyfocus breaks with my change, and how hard it would be to do a translation.

issue.title: [Umbrella] Support gaps

labels.name: accepted
labels.description: Has been approved and is ok to start working on

labels.name: merge-i3-gaps
labels.description: Issues needing to be resolved to deprecate i3-gaps

issue.body:
## Known issues / possible improvements - [ ] Ensure gaps work with titlebars without a compositor: https://github.com/i3/i3/issues/1966 - [ ] Window size isn’t evenly distributed, in particular with large gaps - [ ] Potentially make the gaps configuration no longer order-sensitive --- Original issue text: ## Desired Behavior After a recent discussion between @stapelberg and myself, we would like to reconsider bringing gaps into i3 itself, effectively deprecating i3-gaps. The main rationale here is that there clearly are thousands of users who want gaps. In order to do so, we need to implement not only gaps, but also all of the current i3-gaps features as listed below. This issue serves as an umbrella issue, if necessary we can create separate issues for the individual features. Before work on this can be started, we need to state our expectations: 1. This is **not** about simply porting the gaps patch into i3. The current gaps patch is kept simple enough to make upstream maintenance possible; this means, however, that in many ways it is more of a hack and doesn't live up to our quality expectations. We should therefore consider – and discuss – how gaps can be brought into i3 in a clean way, particularly including support for titlebars. 2. At this point in time, there is no final decision on whether we would merge this. It very much depends on the discussion and the solution we can find. # Gaps This list tracks the core gaps features that need to be supported - [x] Current i3-gaps configuration and command surface: - Configuration: `gaps [inner|outer|horizontal|vertical|top|left|bottom|right] ` - Configuration: `workspace gaps [inner|outer|horizontal|vertical|top|left|bottom|right] ` - Command: `gaps inner|outer|horizontal|vertical|top|right|bottom|left current|all set|plus|minus|toggle ` - [x] Make gaps information properly available on the IPC (required for in-place restart) - [x] Provide tests for gaps We should overall strive to be compatible with i3-gaps to minimize friction, but where sensible we may deviate. For example, workspace-level gaps are currently solved a bit awkward in i3-gaps. # Gaps-related features The following list tracks other features that need to be supported in i3 as well¹. - [x] `smart_gaps on | inverse_outer` - [x] `smart_borders no_gaps`² - [x] `hide_edge_borders smart_no_gaps` ¹ Note that we may choose to rename features if necessary. ² `smart_borders on` is an alias for `hide_edge_borders smart` and will thus be ignored here. Linking related issues for visibility: #1474, #3611, #2890 Please keep the discussion on this issue solely about how to move gaps to i3. Other questions or feature requests should be posted as new issues. As this will likely be a long and technical discussion I will hide any off topic comments. Thank you! ## Environment Output of `i3 --moreversion 2>&-`: 
i3 version: 4.16.1

comment.body:
> Nevertheless, there seems to be a bug in i3-gaps when switching layouts, see [Airblader/i3#301](https://github.com/Airblader/i3/issues/301). It would be nice if this issue was eventually addressed.

Yes, we know. This issue is prominently documented in the userguide (https://build.i3wm.org/docs/userguide.html#gaps), so we don’t need any more reports of it :) You can follow https://github.com/i3/i3/issues/1966 for more details if you’re curious. 

I’ll try and resume further work on this over the weekend.

issue.title: proposal: crypto/x509: add crypto/x509/rootcerts package and rootcerts tag to embed CA root certificates in program

labels.name: Proposal-Crypto
labels.description: Proposal related to crypto packages or other security issues

milestone.title: Proposal
milestone.description:
Proposals that are pending (not yet accepted/rejected).
See https://golang.org/s/proposal-process.

issue.body:
## Proposal

Go programs currently rely on the operating system to provide CA root certificate information in some sort of certificate system store. There are situations, where no such up-to-date CA root certificates are available like (Docker) containers built `FROM scratch` or out of date environments like poorly maintained or no longer updatable systems (e.g. older hardware appliances).

For some environments it is possible for the user of a Go program to add additional CA root certificates via `SSL_CERT_FILE` or `SSL_CERT_DIR`, but this is not the case for all supported environments (e.g. Windows) and it is definitively not user friendly.

Therefore, it is desirable for Go programs to have some mechanism to directly embed CA root certificate information into the program itself, so that they don't have to rely on system store to provide CA root certificates that may be absent (or out of date).

I make the following assumptions, which I think are reasonable:

* adding the CA root certificates into a program should be optional, as it increases the size of the program by approximately 250K (uncompressed), and most programs run in properly maintained systems with an up-to-date certificate system store
* it should be possible to embed CA root certificates when building an arbitrary program
* it should be possible for a program to always embed CA root certificates without requiring any special build step
* the program should always prefer data from the system if available, as it is likely to be more up to date than that included in the program
* the program should allow to override the preference and force the usage of the embeded data (controled by an environment variable, e.g. `GO_ROOTCERTS_ENABLE`)

Given those assumptions, I propose adding a new package `crypto/x509/rootcerts`. Importing this package (as `import _ "crypto/x509/rootcerts"`) will cause CA root certificates to be embedded in the program. Also, building with the build tag `rootcerts` will force the package to be imported, and therefore will cause CA root certificates to be embedded in the program. The embedded CA root certificates will be used if and when no certificate system store is available (or the user forces the usage of the embedded data).

## Source for the CA Root Certificates

I propose to use the [Mozilla Included CA Certificate List](https://wiki.mozilla.org/CA/Included_Certificates), more specifically the [PEM of Root Certificates in Mozilla's Root Store with the Websites (TLS/SSL) Trust Bit Enabled](https://ccadb-public.secure.force.com/mozilla/IncludedRootsPEMTxt?TrustBitsInclude=Websites) as the source for the CA root certificates.

The *Mozilla Included CA Certificate List* is the source for the CA root certificates embeded in the well known products of the Mozilla Foundation like for example **Firefox** (web browser) or **Thunderbird** (email client).

In contrast to most of the other software vendors, Mozilla maintains its *Included CA Certificate List* publicly and distributes it under an open source license (Mozilla Public License Version 2). This is also the reason why most of the Linux distributions, as well as
other free unix derivates and wide spread tools, use this list of CA root certificates as part of their distribution.

Some examples:

* Debian (and its derivates): [ca-certificates](https://packages.debian.org/en/sid/ca-certificates)
* Red Hat / Fedora / CentOS: [ca-certificates](https://src.fedoraproject.org/rpms/ca-certificates) / [ca-certificates](https://centos.pkgs.org/7/centos-x86_64/ca-certificates-2020.2.41-70.0.el7_8.noarch.rpm.html)
* Alpine Linux: [ca-certificates](https://pkgs.alpinelinux.org/package/v3.12/main/x86/ca-certificates)
* FreeBSD: [ca_root_nss](https://www.freshports.org/security/ca_root_nss/)
* NetBSD: [ca-certificates](https://pkgsrc.se/security/ca-certificates)
* curl: [cacert.pem](https://curl.se/docs/caextract.html)

In summary in my opinion it is safe to say that the *Mozilla Included CA Certificate List* is well established and widely used.
In fact, if a Go program is run on Linux or an other free Unix derivate, chances are high that the root certificates used by the program are already provided by the *Mozilla Included CA Certificate List*.

## Why include into the Go Standard Library

As the sample implementation (link in Annex below) clearly demostrates, that it is possible to write a 3rd party Go package, which achieves the same goal as the proposed package `crypto/x509/rootcerts` would. The main difference between a package in the standard library and a 3rd party package is: **TRUST**.

The root certificates are the top-most certificates in the trust chain and used to ensure the trustworthiness of the certificates signed by them either directly (intermediate certificates) or indirectly (through intermediate certificates). Therefore for a package containing and replacing the root certificates, trust is essential.

The same way, most users of Linux trust the CA root certificates provided by their distribution, it is very likely, that user would trust the CA root certificates provided by a package included in the Go standard library.

Additionally, the possibility to include the CA root certificates during build time, without altering the source code, is not possible with a 3rd party package but only if this package is included into the Go standard library and the build tag is implemented in to Go tool chain.

## Update of the CA Root Certificates

The CA Root Certificates included in the standard library are updated with every release of Go (with the current schedule every 6 months). This would work the same way as it currently does for the package `time/tzdata`. The update frequency of the *Included CA Certificate List* is roughly every few months (2020: 5 times, 2019: 4 times, according to [curl ca extract](https://curl.se/docs/caextract.html)), which seems to be similar to the update frequency of the time zone data information.

In regards to updating the CA root certificates compiled into a Go binary, the same limitations apply as for the `time/tzdata` package. The information compiled into a binary is not updated. That being said, for the situations, this package is intended for, it is still an improvement because containers built `FROM scratch` are also not updated by default and out of date / not updatable systems obviously also do not get updates for the CA root certificates.

## Annex

There is a sample implementation of this approach at [github.com/breml/rootcerts](https://github.com/breml/rootcerts) with some additional reasoning about when to use such a package and what to keep in mind.

This proposal as well as the sample implementation are highly influenced by the proposal [#38017 - time/tzdata](https://github.com/golang/go/issues/38017) and the implementation of the package `time/tzdata` by @ianlancetaylor

cc: @FiloSottile, @katiehockman, @mvdan

comment.body:
> How are we doing on this discussion? Do people agree with the most recent API proposal in [#43958 (comment)](https://github.com/golang/go/issues/43958#issuecomment-1284014369) ?

Yes, the proposed `rootcerts.FetchRootsAsPEM` API would work for me AFAICT :)

issue.title: Fix size for TypeTimeHour
issue.body:
Hi,

I have made a small correction in `set.go` for `TypeTimeHour`. The size of the type is set to 8 via `Bytes` field which is incorrect. The correct size should be 4. This is also confirmed in nftables code here: https://git.netfilter.org/nftables/tree/src/meta.c?id=c8a3c669499d169fef8c1e89b8d2d909e5ecd023#n600. The size change was introduced with the following commit: https://git.netfilter.org/nftables/commit/src/meta.c?id=4e1abfc552170d6db5c511634a29918e64c1b51b.

This PR should also fix issue #202.

comment.body: Thanks!

commits.message:
Merge gaps support as-is

This code was copied over unmodified from https://github.com/Airblader/i3-gaps.

I have split out the differences between i3-gaps and i3 into three areas:
1. Gaps
2. i3bar height
3. rgba colors
remove dead code: window_rect is overwritten a few lines below

refactor render_con() global parameter into should_inset_con()

This bundles the logic all in one place and thereby makes it a little easier to
understand.
Fix config.spec comment
gaps: use logical_px() to work correctly on hi-dpi monitors
userguide: document gaps config directive and gaps command
add basic gaps test
gaps: allow optional px suffix
move gaps-specific logic out of con.c and render.c into gaps.c
t/319-gaps.t: also test the gaps command

refactor cmd_gaps to get rid of all #define

I’m still not 100% happy with how the function turned out (it still does too
many things at once), but this seems like an improvement — at least reading and
navigating the code with LSP now works better.
config.spec: add missing smart_gaps inverse_outer comment
meson.build: include new gaps1920.png file in dist tarball (#5242)

issue.title: older Kinesis classic (KB333) compatibility?

labels.name: question
labels.description: Further information is requested

issue.body:
I have gotten two questions regarding compatibility with the older kinesis advantage classic (KB333), which predates the KB500 and KB600 models.

The brief answer is that the kinT is currently not compatible with the older classic version.

The long answer is:

Electrically it is compatible, mechanically it is not compatible. The biggest difference are the connectors to the left and right key wells. Newer kinesis revisions use FFC connectors (FFC = flat form factor cables), but in the older revisions, the key well PCBs are directly connected into the controller (no cable).

Unfortunately I don’t know the part number for the required connector. In the humblehacker blog article, the author says they de-soldered the original connector from the original controller. (So if the keyboard is broken and you’re feeling adventurous, that might be an option.)

If you can figure out which part number one needs, you only need to replace it in the kinT controller design. The footprint should be identical or similar.

The only bit that’s worrying me is the physical position on the controller. With the FFC connectors you have a little wiggle room, but I think when connecting the PCBs directly, everything needs to fit much more precisely. Possibly you need to move the connector to the left or right in the kinT controller design, but that might require moving traces as well…

I hope this gives an impression of the kind and amount of work required to make it work

comment.body: Glad to hear you could get it to work now! :)

comment.diff_hunk:
@@ -1426,6 +1426,95 @@ tiling_drag modifier titlebar
 tiling_drag off
 --------------------------------
 
+[[gaps]]
+=== Gaps
+
+“Gaps” are added spacing between windows (or split containers) and to the screen
+edges:
+
+image::gaps1920.png["Screenshot of i3 with gaps enabled (10 px inner gaps, 20 px outer gaps)",title="Gaps enabled (10 px inner gaps, 20 px outer gaps)"]
+
+You can configure two different kind of gaps:
+
+1. Inner gaps are space between two adjacent windows (or split containers).
+2. Outer gaps are space along the screen edges. You can configure each side
+   (left, right, top, bottom) separately.
+
+If you are familiar with HTML and CSS, you can think of inner gaps as `padding`,
+and of outer gaps as `margin`, applied to a `<div>` around your window or split
+container.
+
+Note that outer gaps are added to the inner gaps, meaning the total gap size
+between a screen edge and a window (or split container) will be the sum of outer
+and inner gaps.
+
+You can define gaps either globally or per workspace using the following
+syntax. Note that the gaps configurations should be ordered from least specific
+to most specific as some directives can overwrite others.
+
+*Syntax*:
+-----------------------
+# Inner gaps for all windows: space between two adjacent windows (or split containers).
+gaps inner <gap_size_in_px>
+
+# Outer gaps for all windows: space along the screen edges.
+gaps outer|horizontal|vertical|top|left|bottom|right <gap_size_in_px>
+
+# Inner and outer gaps for all windows on a specific workspace.
+# <ws> can be a workspace number or name.
+workspace <ws> gaps inner <gap_size_in_px>
+workspace <ws> gaps outer|horizontal|vertical|top|left|bottom|right <gap_size_in_px>
+
+# Enabling “Smart Gaps” means no gaps will be shown when there is
+# precisely one window or split container on the workspace.
+smart_gaps on|off|inverse_outer
comment.body: Done

issue.title: Stapleberg could wake computer from sleep, but not new kinT41
issue.body: I just got a new KA2 w/ a kinT41 (w/ teensy 4.0). I have macOS and, for some reason, I cannot wake my laptop up from sleep using the kinT41. It worked fine with my old KA2 + stapleberg. This is my firmware: https://github.com/aaronjensen/qmk_firmware/tree/aaron/keyboards/kinesis/keymaps/aaronjensen which, aside from mapping, doesn't really have anything custom afaik. Is this a common thing, or is there anything else that I should look at for this type of issue? Thanks!

comment.body: No, the issue is with specific USB stacks, specifically the NXP stack used on the `kint41` and the ChibiOS driver used on the `kint36`.

issue.title: Control+Mod1+Shift+2 does not work on Dell laptop keyboard

labels.name: missing-log
labels.description: Read the CONTRIBUTING.md file for instructions

issue.body:
## I'm submitting a… 
[ ] Bug
[ ] Feature Request
[ ] Documentation Request
[ X] Other (Please describe in detail)
I get a very strange behavior from time to time, it might be related to an underlying bug in i3, so I'm reporting it here. If it's not a bug, I'm sorry to have wasted your time, but the problem is so strange that any help would be appreciated!! ## Current Behavior My configuration file contains: ``` set $mod control+Mod1 # Set keys to **Jump** to specific workspace bindsym $mod+1 workspace $ws1 bindsym $mod+2 workspace $ws2 ... bindsym $mod+9 workspace $ws9 bindsym $mod+0 workspace $ws10 # Set keys to **Move** focused container to specific workspace bindsym $mod+Shift+1 move container to workspace $ws1 bindsym $mod+Shift+2 move container to workspace $ws2 ... bindsym $mod+Shift+9 move container to workspace $ws9 bindsym $mod+Shift+0 move container to workspace $ws10 ``` I did not put all the lines, but I think you get the idea... I'm using Control_L as Control and Alt_L as Mod1. The observed behavior is that: - All the key combinations to **Jump** to workspace always work perfectly. - All the key combinations to **Move** always work perfectly **but the one associated to '2'**, which does not work at all on my current machine (very recent Dell Laptop). But the exact same config works on at least 3 other machines (1 old ASUS laptop, 1 fairly recent HP laptop, 1 very old HP-mini). However, I think I already encountered this problem on some of the other machines from time to time. What I tested: - I thought some other program might be intercepting the key combination => I killed all applets & user processes one by one, until I even reached a very unusable system, but nothing changed - I noticed that, when I have a terminal on (e.g.) ws3 and I hit the key combination to move to ws3 (thus calling a command that does "nothing"), the cursor blinks, whereas when I hit keys for ws2, cursor does not blink at all, so no command seems to be sent/received. - I though it might be a problem of some keys of the combination sending wrong signal => I used `xmodmap -pm/-pke` & `xev` and they show that the keys I use are actually sending the expected keycode/sym, both independently and by pair. - EDIT1: I tested with Control_R as Control => everything works fine! - EDIT2: Out of curiosity, I just plugged in a USB keyboard => everything works fine!!! I'm going crazy!!!! So the problem seems related to the keyboard. Is it possible that the laptop keyboard is buggy only for some key combination? ## Expected Behavior I would expect Ctrl_L+Alt_L+2 to work everywhere. ## Reproduction Instructions Using the configuration provided above should lead to the problem (at least at some times on some machines...) ## Environment Output of `i3 --moreversion 2>&-`: 
Binary i3 version:  4.20.1 (2021-11-03) © 2009 Michael Stapelberg and contributors
Running i3 version: 4.20.1 (2021-11-03) (pid 6855)
Loaded i3 config:
  /home/guillaume.muller/.config/i3/config (main) (last modified: Sat Sep 24 21:39:31 2022, 3192 seconds ago)

The i3 binary you just called: /usr/bin/i3
The i3 binary you are running: i3

- Linux Distribution & Version: "Ubuntu 22.04.1 LTS" (jammy)
- Are you using a compositor (e.g., xcompmgr or compton): no

issue.title: older Kinesis classic (KB333) compatibility?

labels.name: question
labels.description: Further information is requested

issue.body:
I have gotten two questions regarding compatibility with the older kinesis advantage classic (KB333), which predates the KB500 and KB600 models.

The brief answer is that the kinT is currently not compatible with the older classic version.

The long answer is:

Electrically it is compatible, mechanically it is not compatible. The biggest difference are the connectors to the left and right key wells. Newer kinesis revisions use FFC connectors (FFC = flat form factor cables), but in the older revisions, the key well PCBs are directly connected into the controller (no cable).

Unfortunately I don’t know the part number for the required connector. In the humblehacker blog article, the author says they de-soldered the original connector from the original controller. (So if the keyboard is broken and you’re feeling adventurous, that might be an option.)

If you can figure out which part number one needs, you only need to replace it in the kinT controller design. The footprint should be identical or similar.

The only bit that’s worrying me is the physical position on the controller. With the FFC connectors you have a little wiggle room, but I think when connecting the PCBs directly, everything needs to fit much more precisely. Possibly you need to move the connector to the left or right in the kinT controller design, but that might require moving traces as well…

I hope this gives an impression of the kind and amount of work required to make it work

comment.body:
You can also use `debug_config.matrix = true;` setting to easily find out which row/column a key belongs to when you press it: https://michael.stapelberg.ch/posts/2021-05-08-keyboard-input-latency-qmk-kinesis/#finding-the-pins

Your symptom sounds like a faulty soldering connection. Locate the affected row(s)/column(s) and double-check/re-do their soldering.

tiling_drag: Correctly switch to workspace when dragging across outputs (#5141)

Fixes #5089
Add some release notes (#5138)

unflake t/289-ipc-shutdown-event.t (#5144)

Before this commit, the test was flaky: it relied on the Perl test process
sending the kill() system call before i3 exited. This can easily be triggered
by adding a sleep(1) after the “cmd 'exit'” line.

This is because with i3_autostart => 1 (the default), i3test.pm kills i3
or bails out if it can’t.

So, we instead set i3_autostart => 0 and launch i3 ourselves.
This will unfortunately still make the code kill i3 and bail out,
because launch_with_config updates the $i3_pid variable that i3test.pm
uses for tracking whether it should clean up i3.
The solution is to exit i3 by calling exit_gracefully,
which will make the i3test.pm state correct.

https://twitter.com/zekjur/status/1572622368492888065
release.sh: latest released version numbers

release.sh: re-add warning about debian/changelog changes

As long as we push auto builder packages from our CI, we need to update the
version number via the changelog.

GitHub Actions: skip build + test steps in meson dist (#5148)

Originally I thought we should remove the build and test steps in favor of the
“meson dist” step. But, then we lose verbose build command lines and access
to the test logs, and having the failing test logs readily available is
critical.

So, instead, let’s make the “meson dist” step not repeat the work that was
already done in earlier steps. The Meson manual even documents the --no-tests
flag precisely for our use case:

> The meson dist command has a --no-tests option to skip build and tests steps
> of generated packages. It can be used to not waste time for example when done
> in CI that already does its own testing.

From https://mesonbuild.com/Creating-releases.html

fixes https://github.com/i3/i3/issues/5145

labels.name: merge-i3-gaps
labels.description: Issues needing to be resolved to deprecate i3-gaps

issue.body:
## I'm submitting a… 
[ ] Bug
[x] Feature Request
[ ] Documentation Request
[ ] Other (Please describe in detail)
## Desired Behavior After a recent discussion between @stapelberg and myself, we would like to reconsider bringing gaps into i3 itself, effectively deprecating i3-gaps. The main rationale here is that there clearly are thousands of users who want gaps. In order to do so, we need to implement not only gaps, but also all of the current i3-gaps features as listed below. This issue serves as an umbrella issue, if necessary we can create separate issues for the individual features. Before work on this can be started, we need to state our expectations: 1. This is **not** about simply porting the gaps patch into i3. The current gaps patch is kept simple enough to make upstream maintenance possible; this means, however, that in many ways it is more of a hack and doesn't live up to our quality expectations. We should therefore consider – and discuss – how gaps can be brought into i3 in a clean way, particularly including support for titlebars. 2. At this point in time, there is no final decision on whether we would merge this. It very much depends on the discussion and the solution we can find. # Gaps This list tracks the core gaps features that need to be supported - [ ] Current i3-gaps configuration and command surface: - Configuration: `gaps [inner|outer|horizontal|vertical|top|left|bottom|right] ` - Configuration: `workspace gaps [inner|outer|horizontal|vertical|top|left|bottom|right] ` - Command: `gaps inner|outer|horizontal|vertical|top|right|bottom|left current|all set|plus|minus|toggle ` - [ ] Make gaps information properly available on the IPC (required for in-place restart) - [ ] Ensure gaps work with titlebars without a compositor: https://github.com/i3/i3/issues/1966 - [ ] Provide tests for gaps - [ ] Window size isn’t evenly distributed, in particular with large gaps We should overall strive to be compatible with i3-gaps to minimize friction, but where sensible we may deviate. For example, workspace-level gaps are currently solved a bit awkward in i3-gaps. # Gaps-related features The following list tracks other features that need to be supported in i3 as well¹. - [ ] `smart_gaps on | inverse_outer` - [ ] `smart_borders no_gaps`² - [ ] `hide_edge_borders smart_no_gaps` ¹ Note that we may choose to rename features if necessary. ² `smart_borders on` is an alias for `hide_edge_borders smart` and will thus be ignored here. Linking related issues for visibility: #1474, #3611, #2890 Please keep the discussion on this issue solely about how to move gaps to i3. Other questions or feature requests should be posted as new issues. As this will likely be a long and technical discussion I will hide any off topic comments. Thank you! ## Environment Output of `i3 --moreversion 2>&-`: 
i3 version: 4.16.1

comment.body:
Thanks for the extra infos. Yeah, let’s keep the behavior as-is for the `gaps` command then.

I added the part about un-evenly distributed sizes to the list in the first comment of this issue.

commits.message: delete old release notes

Merge gaps support as-is

This code was copied over unmodified from https://github.com/Airblader/i3-gaps.

I have split out the differences between i3-gaps and i3 into three areas:
1. Gaps
2. i3bar height
3. rgba colors
remove dead code: window_rect is overwritten a few lines below

refactor render_con() global parameter into should_inset_con()

This bundles the logic all in one place and thereby makes it a little easier to
understand.

docs/userguide: fix asciidoc block syntax (for asciidoctor)

asciidoctor is a bit stricter in what it accepts: the leading and trailing lines
need to have the exact same number of characters, and apparently there needs to
be a blank line after the trailing delimiter line.
Fix config.spec comment
gaps: use logical_px() to work correctly on hi-dpi monitors
userguide: document gaps config directive and gaps command

comment.body:
I updated your list to also mention the `gaps` command currently operating on workspaces. I think it would be more useful if the command operated on windows/containers. It can still be used on the workspace level, but could also be used on a window level.

That said, I’m not sure how many people use the `gaps` command at runtime at all — personally, I would just use the `gaps` config directive once. Do people need specific gap sizes for specific types of windows? If so, in which situations (examples please)?

---

I have also updated my branch to contain an initial userguide change. If you know of more limitations compared to what I’m describing there, please let me know :)

issue.title: s/conflicting packages/other packages/
issue.body: The term "conflicting packages" is inaccurate, because with the alternatives system, multiple packages can provide the same man page without conflicting with each other.

comment.body:
You’re right in that the packages don’t conflict with each other at the Debian package level, but from a logical perspective (detached from any technical details), there still is a conflict: there are multiple manual pages for the same name.

I don’t mind changing the terminology to be more descriptive, but at the same time, I’m not convinced that switching from “conflicting” to “other” is an improvement: “other” isn’t describing anything at all. As a reader, I can ask “sure, it’s another package, but what’s the relationship?”

I’m inclined to leave it as “conflicting”

issue.title: Missing alternative: pager → more
issue.body:
`util-linux` installs `more.1` as an alternative for `pager.1`, but is not listed on <https://manpages.debian.org/unstable/less/pager.1.en.html>.
I guess it's because the package is essential?

comment.body:
You can learn more about how the alternatives integration works in https://github.com/Debian/debiman/issues/12

When I download https://piuparts.debian.org/for-manpages.d.o/sid.json.gz, I don’t see an entry for `util-linux`. Maybe you can take a look and figure out what’s wrong?

comment.body:
No, sur5r has taken over the Debian packaging work since i3 v4.17 (thank you!)

I have considered doing a release with this feature earlier than the usual cadence because of its significance. 

The earliest I can imagine is early/mid December, or possibly January depending on how many user reports we get in terms of breakage or successful test reports.

Debian’s soft freeze starts at 2023-02-12, so with a release in January (preferably early), that would leave sur5r a few weeks to upload it to Debian to make it into bookworm.

issue.title: Allow text drawing to use the alpha channel.
issue.body:
This is the last remaining diff from the i3-gaps tree.

related to https://github.com/i3/i3/issues/3724

Tested using the following config with picom:
```
bar {
	i3bar_command i3bar -t
	status_command i3status
	colors {
		# fully	transparent text on opaque background:
		statusline #ffffff00
		background #000000ff
	}
}
```

comment.body:

Updated. Were those the places / phrasing you had in mind? Not sure I 100% captured all effects of this change :)

issue.title: Allow text drawing to use the alpha channel.

This is the last remaining diff from the i3-gaps tree.

related to https://github.com/i3/i3/issues/3724

Tested using the following config with picom:
```
bar {
	i3bar_command i3bar -t

comment.body:
> LGTM. But I think this forces our hand on closing #3947, right?

No, I don’t think we necessarily have to close it — we could still accept the compromise of conditionally using either operator depending on the alpha channel. But it seems like (most of?) the PR’s motivation might no longer apply anyway: https://github.com/i3/i3/pull/3947#issuecomment-1304573171

issue.body:
@stapelberg I wonder if there is a good reason why we draw window decorations on the parent container? I understand that it's a design decision that is deeply integrated into the i3 code, but I'd still like to figure out whether it's something we could consider changing given someone does the work.

For stacked and tabbed containers it makes a lot of sense, but I'm not sure this applies to vertically or horizontally split containers as well.
- Is there an actual, technical reason for this? Can we anticipate changes other than the rendering that would become necessary?
- Is it something that could be considered to be changed?

i3 4.10.4

issue.title: Starting containers fails
issue.body:
I ran through the instructions in the README (which is, BTW, different from the ones [on the website](https://gokrazy.org/packages/docker-containers/)) and when it came to running a container, I got the following error messages:

```go
/tmp/breakglass4160648770 # podman run --rm -ti docker.io/library/debian:sid
Trying to pull docker.io/library/debian:sid...
Getting image source signatures
Copying blob 63a396bb133c done  
Copying config dba65145f2 done  
Writing manifest to image destination
Storing signatures
WARN[0051] Failed to load cached network config: network podman not found in CNI cache, falling back to loading network podman from disk 
WARN[0051] 1 error occurred:                        
                            	* plugin type="cni-nftables-firewall" failed (delete): cni plugin cni-nftables-firewall failed: cni-nftables-firewall.Del() error: failed validating input: the data passed to firewall plugin did not contain network interfaces
   
Error: plugin type="bridge" failed (add): cni plugin bridge failed: failed to create bridge "cni-podman0": could not add "cni-podman0": operation not supported
```

I don't know enough about all of this to know where to even start debugging this further. 

I have `/perm/container-storage` bind-mounted to `/var`. Version info from the web interface is

```
version 2022-11-04T21:04:24+01:00
host	gokrazy
kernel	Linux 5.7.6 (aarch64)
model	Raspberry Pi 3 Model B Rev 1.2
```

Any hints on what to try?

comment.body:
> I feel with the way it works now `builddir` is a misnomer. `builddir`, to me, suggests that it's a temporary directory for build artifacts, whereas it seems to rather be a source of truth.
> 
> Obviously, it works the way it works. I think there are better alternatives, but this doesn't seem the right place and time to discuss it.

Yes, it’s definitely a source of truth (for the build of each package, hence the current name). I’m open for better names if you have one :) 

> I have instance-specific code. It needs to live in a module. AIUI (now) I should perhaps put that into `builddir`, though.

No, I don’t think it should go into a builddir. In the builddir, only go.mod and go.sum are expected to be present.

What are you trying to achieve by moving your module/package’s code into the builddir?

issue.body:
I ran through the instructions in the README (which is, BTW, different from the ones [on the website](https://gokrazy.org/packages/docker-containers/)) and when it came to running a container, I got the following error messages:

```go
/tmp/breakglass4160648770 # podman run --rm -ti docker.io/library/debian:sid
Trying to pull docker.io/library/debian:sid...
Getting image source signatures
Copying blob 63a396bb133c done

WARN[0051] 1 error occurred:                        
                            	* plugin type="cni-nftables-firewall" failed (delete): cni plugin cni-nftables-firewall failed: cni-nftables-firewall.Del() error: failed validating input: the data passed to firewall plugin did not contain network interfaces
   
Error: plugin type="bridge" failed (add): cni plugin bridge failed: failed to create bridge "cni-podman0": could not add "cni-podman0": operation not supported
```

I don't know enough about all of this to know where to even start debugging this further. 

I have `/perm/container-storage` bind-mounted to `/var`. Version info from the web interface is

```
version 2022-11-04T21:04:24+01:00
host	gokrazy
kernel	Linux 5.7.6 (aarch64)
model	Raspberry Pi 3 Model B Rev 1.2
```

Any hints on what to try?

comment.body:
> But I used a new `gokr-packer`, I would expect that to pick up new versions of the kernel and other packages…

The packer never updates for you (I think the `go` tool doesn’t, either). In my update script, I do:

```bash
for instance in dr bakery scan2drive bakeryapu2c4 consrv; do
    echo "pulling instance $instance"
    cd ~/gokrazy/$instance/builddir/github.com/gokrazy/gokrazy
    go get github.com/gokrazy/gokrazy@latest

    if [ "$instance" = "bakeryapu2c4" ]
    then
	cd ~/gokrazy/$instance/builddir/github.com/rtr7/kernel
	go get github.com/rtr7/kernel@latest
    else
	cd ~/gokrazy/$instance/builddir/github.com/gokrazy/kernel
	go get github.com/gokrazy/kernel@latest

	cd ~/gokrazy/$instance/builddir/github.com/gokrazy/firmware
	go get github.com/gokrazy/firmware@latest

	cd ~/gokrazy/$instance/builddir/github.com/gokrazy/rpi-eeprom
	go get github.com/gokrazy/rpi-eeprom@latest
    fi
done

```

(Plus some update-specific instance logic where appropriate, but for some programs it’s a feature that they won’t get updated until I say so.)

> or use the one from the `go.mod` in the current module

It does that, but the “current module” is in the builddir. The top-level go.mod is only used as a template for creating new builddirs where necessary (which can be useful if you want e.g. `replace` directives to apply to all new modules).

It might be clearer to delete any top-level go.mod you have in your instance directories.

comment.body:
> This closes #1966 I believe

Yep, the “fixes #1966” is already in the commit message (but not on the pull request level).

> I also wonder how you're feeling about [#1966 (comment)](https://github.com/i3/i3/issues/1966#issuecomment-158684486)?

I haven’t thought it through in detail.

On one hand, one could say that the deco_rect semantics are unchanged, only the rendering has changed — the deco_rect still specifies *where* the decoration is drawn, but now the drawing happens on a different X11 window.

I think the way we interpreted “retain semantics” in the past (at least in that issue) is to translate coordinates in such a way that the x/y position still matches the absolute position on screen where decorations appear today.

I wonder how widely used the deco_rect is by IPC interface users at all. The only usages I can find on GitHub Code Search that might be affected are https://github.com/cornerman/i3-easyfocus and https://github.com/kraftwerk28/dotfiles/blob/bd081348da1dfdc126db95563b534a7669e990bd/bin/grimvshot#L35

I’ll try and see if i3-easyfocus breaks with my change, and how hard it would be to do a translation.

issue.title: [Umbrella] Support gaps

labels.name: accepted
labels.description: Has been approved and is ok to start working on

labels.name: merge-i3-gaps
labels.description: Issues needing to be resolved to deprecate i3-gaps

issue.body:
## Known issues / possible improvements - [ ] Ensure gaps work with titlebars without a compositor: https://github.com/i3/i3/issues/1966 - [ ] Window size isn’t evenly distributed, in particular with large gaps - [ ] Potentially make the gaps configuration no longer order-sensitive --- Original issue text: ## Desired Behavior After a recent discussion between @stapelberg and myself, we would like to reconsider bringing gaps into i3 itself, effectively deprecating i3-gaps. The main rationale here is that there clearly are thousands of users who want gaps. In order to do so, we need to implement not only gaps, but also all of the current i3-gaps features as listed below. This issue serves as an umbrella issue, if necessary we can create separate issues for the individual features. Before work on this can be started, we need to state our expectations: 1. This is **not** about simply porting the gaps patch into i3. The current gaps patch is kept simple enough to make upstream maintenance possible; this means, however, that in many ways it is more of a hack and doesn't live up to our quality expectations. We should therefore consider – and discuss – how gaps can be brought into i3 in a clean way, particularly including support for titlebars. 2. At this point in time, there is no final decision on whether we would merge this. It very much depends on the discussion and the solution we can find. # Gaps This list tracks the core gaps features that need to be supported - [x] Current i3-gaps configuration and command surface: - Configuration: `gaps [inner|outer|horizontal|vertical|top|left|bottom|right] ` - Configuration: `workspace gaps [inner|outer|horizontal|vertical|top|left|bottom|right] ` - Command: `gaps inner|outer|horizontal|vertical|top|right|bottom|left current|all set|plus|minus|toggle ` - [x] Make gaps information properly available on the IPC (required for in-place restart) - [x] Provide tests for gaps We should overall strive to be compatible with i3-gaps to minimize friction, but where sensible we may deviate. For example, workspace-level gaps are currently solved a bit awkward in i3-gaps. # Gaps-related features The following list tracks other features that need to be supported in i3 as well¹. - [x] `smart_gaps on | inverse_outer` - [x] `smart_borders no_gaps`² - [x] `hide_edge_borders smart_no_gaps` ¹ Note that we may choose to rename features if necessary. ² `smart_borders on` is an alias for `hide_edge_borders smart` and will thus be ignored here. Linking related issues for visibility: #1474, #3611, #2890 Please keep the discussion on this issue solely about how to move gaps to i3. Other questions or feature requests should be posted as new issues. As this will likely be a long and technical discussion I will hide any off topic comments. Thank you! ## Environment Output of `i3 --moreversion 2>&-`: 
i3 version: 4.16.1

comment.body:
> Nevertheless, there seems to be a bug in i3-gaps when switching layouts, see [Airblader/i3#301](https://github.com/Airblader/i3/issues/301). It would be nice if this issue was eventually addressed.

Yes, we know. This issue is prominently documented in the userguide (https://build.i3wm.org/docs/userguide.html#gaps), so we don’t need any more reports of it :) You can follow https://github.com/i3/i3/issues/1966 for more details if you’re curious. 

I’ll try and resume further work on this over the weekend.

issue.title: proposal: crypto/x509: add crypto/x509/rootcerts package and rootcerts tag to embed CA root certificates in program

labels.name: Proposal-Crypto
labels.description: Proposal related to crypto packages or other security issues

milestone.title: Proposal
milestone.description:
Proposals that are pending (not yet accepted/rejected).
See https://golang.org/s/proposal-process.

issue.body:
## Proposal

Go programs currently rely on the operating system to provide CA root certificate information in some sort of certificate system store. There are situations, where no such up-to-date CA root certificates are available like (Docker) containers built `FROM scratch` or out of date environments like poorly maintained or no longer updatable systems (e.g. older hardware appliances).

For some environments it is possible for the user of a Go program to add additional CA root certificates via `SSL_CERT_FILE` or `SSL_CERT_DIR`, but this is not the case for all supported environments (e.g. Windows) and it is definitively not user friendly.

Therefore, it is desirable for Go programs to have some mechanism to directly embed CA root certificate information into the program itself, so that they don't have to rely on system store to provide CA root certificates that may be absent (or out of date).

I make the following assumptions, which I think are reasonable:

* adding the CA root certificates into a program should be optional, as it increases the size of the program by approximately 250K (uncompressed), and most programs run in properly maintained systems with an up-to-date certificate system store
* it should be possible to embed CA root certificates when building an arbitrary program
* it should be possible for a program to always embed CA root certificates without requiring any special build step
* the program should always prefer data from the system if available, as it is likely to be more up to date than that included in the program
* the program should allow to override the preference and force the usage of the embeded data (controled by an environment variable, e.g. `GO_ROOTCERTS_ENABLE`)

Given those assumptions, I propose adding a new package `crypto/x509/rootcerts`. Importing this package (as `import _ "crypto/x509/rootcerts"`) will cause CA root certificates to be embedded in the program. Also, building with the build tag `rootcerts` will force the package to be imported, and therefore will cause CA root certificates to be embedded in the program. The embedded CA root certificates will be used if and when no certificate system store is available (or the user forces the usage of the embedded data).

## Source for the CA Root Certificates

I propose to use the [Mozilla Included CA Certificate List](https://wiki.mozilla.org/CA/Included_Certificates), more specifically the [PEM of Root Certificates in Mozilla's Root Store with the Websites (TLS/SSL) Trust Bit Enabled](https://ccadb-public.secure.force.com/mozilla/IncludedRootsPEMTxt?TrustBitsInclude=Websites) as the source for the CA root certificates.

The *Mozilla Included CA Certificate List* is the source for the CA root certificates embeded in the well known products of the Mozilla Foundation like for example **Firefox** (web browser) or **Thunderbird** (email client).

In contrast to most of the other software vendors, Mozilla maintains its *Included CA Certificate List* publicly and distributes it under an open source license (Mozilla Public License Version 2). This is also the reason why most of the Linux distributions, as well as
other free unix derivates and wide spread tools, use this list of CA root certificates as part of their distribution.

Some examples:

* Debian (and its derivates): [ca-certificates](https://packages.debian.org/en/sid/ca-certificates)
* Red Hat / Fedora / CentOS: [ca-certificates](https://src.fedoraproject.org/rpms/ca-certificates) / [ca-certificates](https://centos.pkgs.org/7/centos-x86_64/ca-certificates-2020.2.41-70.0.el7_8.noarch.rpm.html)
* Alpine Linux: [ca-certificates](https://pkgs.alpinelinux.org/package/v3.12/main/x86/ca-certificates)
* FreeBSD: [ca_root_nss](https://www.freshports.org/security/ca_root_nss/)
* NetBSD: [ca-certificates](https://pkgsrc.se/security/ca-certificates)
* curl: [cacert.pem](https://curl.se/docs/caextract.html)

In summary in my opinion it is safe to say that the *Mozilla Included CA Certificate List* is well established and widely used.
In fact, if a Go program is run on Linux or an other free Unix derivate, chances are high that the root certificates used by the program are already provided by the *Mozilla Included CA Certificate List*.

## Why include into the Go Standard Library

As the sample implementation (link in Annex below) clearly demostrates, that it is possible to write a 3rd party Go package, which achieves the same goal as the proposed package `crypto/x509/rootcerts` would. The main difference between a package in the standard library and a 3rd party package is: **TRUST**.

The root certificates are the top-most certificates in the trust chain and used to ensure the trustworthiness of the certificates signed by them either directly (intermediate certificates) or indirectly (through intermediate certificates). Therefore for a package containing and replacing the root certificates, trust is essential.

The same way, most users of Linux trust the CA root certificates provided by their distribution, it is very likely, that user would trust the CA root certificates provided by a package included in the Go standard library.

Additionally, the possibility to include the CA root certificates during build time, without altering the source code, is not possible with a 3rd party package but only if this package is included into the Go standard library and the build tag is implemented in to Go tool chain.

## Update of the CA Root Certificates

The CA Root Certificates included in the standard library are updated with every release of Go (with the current schedule every 6 months). This would work the same way as it currently does for the package `time/tzdata`. The update frequency of the *Included CA Certificate List* is roughly every few months (2020: 5 times, 2019: 4 times, according to [curl ca extract](https://curl.se/docs/caextract.html)), which seems to be similar to the update frequency of the time zone data information.

In regards to updating the CA root certificates compiled into a Go binary, the same limitations apply as for the `time/tzdata` package. The information compiled into a binary is not updated. That being said, for the situations, this package is intended for, it is still an improvement because containers built `FROM scratch` are also not updated by default and out of date / not updatable systems obviously also do not get updates for the CA root certificates.

## Annex

There is a sample implementation of this approach at [github.com/breml/rootcerts](https://github.com/breml/rootcerts) with some additional reasoning about when to use such a package and what to keep in mind.

This proposal as well as the sample implementation are highly influenced by the proposal [#38017 - time/tzdata](https://github.com/golang/go/issues/38017) and the implementation of the package `time/tzdata` by @ianlancetaylor

cc: @FiloSottile, @katiehockman, @mvdan

comment.body:
> How are we doing on this discussion? Do people agree with the most recent API proposal in [#43958 (comment)](https://github.com/golang/go/issues/43958#issuecomment-1284014369) ?

Yes, the proposed `rootcerts.FetchRootsAsPEM` API would work for me AFAICT :)

For example, workspace-level gaps are currently solved a bit awkward in i3-gaps. # Gaps-related features The following list tracks other features that need to be supported in i3 as well¹. - [x] `smart_gaps on | inverse_outer` - [x] `smart_borders no_gaps`² - [x] `hide_edge_borders smart_no_gaps` ¹ Note that we may choose to rename features if necessary. ² `smart_borders on` is an alias for `hide_edge_borders smart` and will thus be ignored here. Linking related issues for visibility: #1474, #3611, #2890 Please keep the discussion on this issue solely about how to move gaps to i3. Other questions or feature requests should be posted as new issues. As this will likely be a long and technical discussion I will hide any off topic comments. issue.title: Fix size for TypeTimeHour
issue.body:
Hi,

I have made a small correction in `set.go` for `TypeTimeHour`. The size of the type is set to 8 via `Bytes` field which is incorrect. The correct size should be 4. This is also confirmed in nftables code here: https://git.netfilter.org/nftables/tree/src/meta.c?id=c8a3c669499d169fef8c1e89b8d2d909e5ecd023#n600. The size change was introduced with the following commit: https://git.netfilter.org/nftables/commit/src/meta.c?id=4e1abfc552170d6db5c511634a29918e64c1b51b.

This PR should also fix issue #202.

issue.body:
## Known issues / possible improvements - [ ] Ensure gaps work with titlebars without a compositor: https://github.com/i3/i3/issues/1966 - [ ] Window size isn’t evenly distributed, in particular with large gaps - [ ] Potentially make the gaps configuration no longer order-sensitive --- Original issue text: ## Desired Behavior After a recent discussion between @stapelberg and myself, we would like to reconsider bringing gaps into i3 itself, effectively deprecating i3-gaps. The main rationale here is that there clearly are thousands of users who want gaps. In order to do so, we need to implement not only gaps, but also all of the current i3-gaps features as listed below. This issue serves as an umbrella issue, if necessary we can create separate issues for the individual features. Before work on this can be started, we need to state our expectations: 1. This is **not** about simply porting the gaps patch into i3. The current gaps patch is kept simple enough to make upstream maintenance possible; this means, however, that in many ways it is more of a hack and doesn't live up to our quality expectations. We should therefore consider – and discuss – how gaps can be brought into i3 in a clean way, particularly including support for titlebars. 2. At this point in time, there is no final decision on whether we would merge this. It very much depends on the discussion and the solution we can find. # Gaps This list tracks the core gaps features that need to be supported - [x] Current i3-gaps configuration and command surface: - Configuration: `gaps [inner|outer|horizontal|vertical|top|left|bottom|right] ` - Configuration: `workspace gaps [inner|outer|horizontal|vertical|top|left|bottom|right] ` - Command: `gaps inner|outer|horizontal|vertical|top|right|bottom|left current|all set|plus|minus|toggle ` - [x] Make gaps information properly available on the IPC (required for in-place restart) - [x] Provide tests for gaps We should overall strive to be compatible with i3-gaps to minimize friction, but where sensible we may deviate. For example, workspace-level gaps are currently solved a bit awkward in i3-gaps. # Gaps-related features The following list tracks other features that need to be supported in i3 as well¹. - [x] `smart_gaps on | inverse_outer` - [x] `smart_borders no_gaps`² - [x] `hide_edge_borders smart_no_gaps` ¹ Note that we may choose to rename features if necessary. ² `smart_borders on` is an alias for `hide_edge_borders smart` and will thus be ignored here. Linking related issues for visibility: #1474, #3611, #2890 Please keep the discussion on this issue solely about how to move gaps to i3. Other questions or feature requests should be posted as new issues. As this will likely be a long and technical discussion I will hide any off topic comments. Thank you! ## Environment Output of `i3 --moreversion 2>&-`: 
i3 version: 4.16.1

issue.title: older Kinesis classic (KB333) compatibility?

labels.name: question
labels.description: Further information is requested

issue.body:
I have gotten two questions regarding compatibility with the older kinesis advantage classic (KB333), which predates the KB500 and KB600 models.

The brief answer is that the kinT is currently not compatible with the older classic version.

The long answer is:

Electrically it is compatible, mechanically it is not compatible. The biggest difference are the connectors to the left and right key wells. Newer kinesis revisions use FFC connectors (FFC = flat form factor cables), but in the older revisions, the key well PCBs are directly connected into the controller (no cable).

Unfortunately I don’t know the part number for the required connector. In the humblehacker blog article, the author says they de-soldered the original connector from the original controller. (So if the keyboard is broken and you’re feeling adventurous, that might be an option.)

If you can figure out which part number one needs, you only need to replace it in the kinT controller design. The footprint should be identical or similar.

The only bit that’s worrying me is the physical position on the controller. With the FFC connectors you have a little wiggle room, but I think when connecting the PCBs directly, everything needs to fit much more precisely. Possibly you need to move the connector to the left or right in the kinT controller design, but that might require moving traces as well…

I hope this gives an impression of the kind and amount of work required to make it work

comment.body: Glad to hear you could get it to work now! :)

comment.diff_hunk:
@@ -1426,6 +1426,95 @@ tiling_drag modifier titlebar
 tiling_drag off
 --------------------------------
 
+[[gaps]]
+=== Gaps
+
+“Gaps” are added spacing between windows (or split containers) and to the screen
+edges:
+
+image::gaps1920.png["Screenshot of i3 with gaps enabled (10 px inner gaps, 20 px outer gaps)",title="Gaps enabled (10 px inner gaps, 20 px outer gaps)"]
+
+You can configure two different kind of gaps:
+
+1. Inner gaps are space between two adjacent windows (or split containers).
+2. Outer gaps are space along the screen edges. You can configure each side
+   (left, right, top, bottom) separately.
+
+If you are familiar with HTML and CSS, you can think of inner gaps as `padding`,
+and of outer gaps as `margin`, applied to a `<div>` around your window or split
+container.
+
+Note that outer gaps are added to the inner gaps, meaning the total gap size
+between a screen edge and a window (or split container) will be the sum of outer
+and inner gaps.
+
+You can define gaps either globally or per workspace using the following
+syntax. Note that the gaps configurations should be ordered from least specific
+to most specific as some directives can overwrite others.
+
+*Syntax*:
+-----------------------
+# Inner gaps for all windows: space between two adjacent windows (or split containers).
+gaps inner <gap_size_in_px>
+
+# Outer gaps for all windows: space along the screen edges.
+gaps outer|horizontal|vertical|top|left|bottom|right <gap_size_in_px>
+
+# Inner and outer gaps for all windows on a specific workspace.
+# <ws> can be a workspace number or name.
+workspace <ws> gaps inner <gap_size_in_px>
+workspace <ws> gaps outer|horizontal|vertical|top|left|bottom|right <gap_size_in_px>
+
+# Enabling “Smart Gaps” means no gaps will be shown when there is
+# precisely one window or split container on the workspace.
+smart_gaps on|off|inverse_outer
comment.body: Done

issue.title: Stapleberg could wake computer from sleep, but not new kinT41
issue.body: I just got a new KA2 w/ a kinT41 (w/ teensy 4.0). I have macOS and, for some reason, I cannot wake my laptop up from sleep using the kinT41. It worked fine with my old KA2 + stapleberg. This is my firmware: https://github.com/aaronjensen/qmk_firmware/tree/aaron/keyboards/kinesis/keymaps/aaronjensen which, aside from mapping, doesn't really have anything custom afaik. Is this a common thing, or is there anything else that I should look at for this type of issue? Thanks!

comment.body: No, the issue is with specific USB stacks, specifically the NXP stack used on the `kint41` and the ChibiOS driver used on the `kint36`.

issue.title: Control+Mod1+Shift+2 does not work on Dell laptop keyboard

labels.name: missing-log
labels.description: Read the CONTRIBUTING.md file for instructions

issue.body:
## I'm submitting a… 
[ ] Bug
[ ] Feature Request
[ ] Documentation Request
[ X] Other (Please describe in detail)
I get a very strange behavior from time to time, it might be related to an underlying bug in i3, so I'm reporting it here. If it's not a bug, I'm sorry to have wasted your time, but the problem is so strange that any help would be appreciated!! ## Current Behavior My configuration file contains: ``` set $mod control+Mod1 # Set keys to **Jump** to specific workspace bindsym $mod+1 workspace $ws1 bindsym $mod+2 workspace $ws2 ... bindsym $mod+9 workspace $ws9 bindsym $mod+0 workspace $ws10 # Set keys to **Move** focused container to specific workspace bindsym $mod+Shift+1 move container to workspace $ws1 bindsym $mod+Shift+2 move container to workspace $ws2 ... bindsym $mod+Shift+9 move container to workspace $ws9 bindsym $mod+Shift+0 move container to workspace $ws10 ``` I did not put all the lines, but I think you get the idea... I'm using Control_L as Control and Alt_L as Mod1. The observed behavior is that: - All the key combinations to **Jump** to workspace always work perfectly. - All the key combinations to **Move** always work perfectly **but the one associated to '2'**, which does not work at all on my current machine (very recent Dell Laptop). But the exact same config works on at least 3 other machines (1 old ASUS laptop, 1 fairly recent HP laptop, 1 very old HP-mini). However, I think I already encountered this problem on some of the other machines from time to time. What I tested: - I thought some other program might be intercepting the key combination => I killed all applets & user processes one by one, until I even reached a very unusable system, but nothing changed - I noticed that, when I have a terminal on (e.g.) ws3 and I hit the key combination to move to ws3 (thus calling a command that does "nothing"), the cursor blinks, whereas when I hit keys for ws2, cursor does not blink at all, so no command seems to be sent/received. - I though it might be a problem of some keys of the combination sending wrong signal => I used `xmodmap -pm/-pke` & `xev` and they show that the keys I use are actually sending the expected keycode/sym, both independently and by pair. - EDIT1: I tested with Control_R as Control => everything works fine! - EDIT2: Out of curiosity, I just plugged in a USB keyboard => everything works fine!!! I'm going crazy!!!! So the problem seems related to the keyboard. Is it possible that the laptop keyboard is buggy only for some key combination? ## Expected Behavior I would expect Ctrl_L+Alt_L+2 to work everywhere. ## Reproduction Instructions Using the configuration provided above should lead to the problem (at least at some times on some machines...) ## Environment Output of `i3 --moreversion 2>&-`: 
Binary i3 version:  4.20.1 (2021-11-03) © 2009 Michael Stapelberg and contributors
Running i3 version: 4.20.1 (2021-11-03) (pid 6855)
Loaded i3 config:
  /home/guillaume.muller/.config/i3/config (main) (last modified: Sat Sep 24 21:39:31 2022, 3192 seconds ago)

The i3 binary you just called: /usr/bin/i3
